etymology.description: Pictogram: face/head of a ghost/spirit/demon; possibly a mask (per Shuowen).
etymology.interpretation: Depicts a stylized spirit’s head, matching early graphic traditions where facial features were simplified into a compact emblem. Some scholars see it as a ritual mask, which would explain the squared, mask-like outline in archaic forms.

examples.chinese: 古文字中的“甶”表示鬼的头部(古文字中的「甶」表示鬼的頭部)。
examples.pinyin: Gǔ wénzì zhōng de “fú” biǎoshì guǐ de tóubù.
examples.english: In ancient writing, 甶 denotes the head of a ghost.

examples.chinese: 据《说文》，甶为象形字，也可能代表面具(據《說文》，甶為象形字，也可能代表面具)。
examples.pinyin: Jù “Shuōwén”, fú wéi xiàngxíngzì, yě kěnéng dàibiǎo miànjù.
examples.english: According to Shuowen, 甶 is a pictograph and may also represent a mask.

examples.chinese: 在现代汉语中，甶很少单独使用，多见于古文字研究(在現代漢語中，甶很少單獨使用，多見於古文字研究)。
examples.pinyin: Zài xiàndài Hànyǔ zhōng, fú hěn shǎo dāndú shǐyòng, duō jiàn yú gǔ wénzì yánjiū.
examples.english: In modern Chinese, 甶 is rarely used alone and is mostly seen in the study of ancient scripts.
